author: velorum6
content:
Hi, I'm doing some research on consensus methods and I'm stuck on the part of how the network understands that transactions hashed by miners have not been manipulated and therefore are valid.

I have tried to look for information about this exactly on the internet but all the texts that talk about this topic, simply assume that this happens this way and I have not found what I want exactly, I know that here you do not answer those questions, but is there any place where I can ask these questions or where there are more technical explanations?. Thank you.

author: 3xmd1559sporebraytondingo
content: The transactions can be reordered without their validity changing in the case of bitcoin. I'm not sure whether this is the case in ethereum.

author: 3xmd1559sporebraytondingo
content: Miners still don't know the private keys to the addresses signing the transactions, so they can't change the contents of the transactions nor which address may receive funds.

author: 3xmd1559sporebraytondingo
content: There's a vitalik.ca article that words it along the lines of "MEV (miner extractable value) is large but bounded" since miners can reorder or censor (exclude a transaction) but they can't sign fraudulent transactions. If there were a fraudulent tx then when someone checks it, they'll realise it's invalid. Can't recall the article, but this is a solid explainer: https://youtu.be/bBC-nXj3Ng4

author: velorum6
content:
That makes sense, I was aware of how MEV worked and seeing that the miners had some freedom in how to place transactions I wanted to find out exactly how the method worked to confirm that the transactions were valid and not manipulated by the miners.

I watched the video and it helped me to understand how the transactions are verified with the user's signature.

Thank you <@!339771292884664320>

author: scottypoi
content:
I have been putting together a website as a resource for SSZ - SimpleSerialize.  Here you can find the actual specs, as well as an overview and guide that I have compiled from various people's blogs and message boards.  As an 'outsider' looking in, I have done my best to organize the information out in a helpful way.  Now that a 'mostly' functioning website is deployed, I would appreciate any feedback or contributions from the community, both from those trying to learn about SSZ, and from those who know it better than I and can correct my mistakes, and fill in the gaps. 

Currently I am working on the next phase of the site, which involves actually visualizing and demonstrating the functions of SSZ in an interactive playground.
